sections.title: Final Campaigns in the South and the Philistine Plain

verses.text: When the nations surrounding them heard that the altar had been rebuilt and the sanctuary rededicated as it was before, they became furious,
verses.comment: This verse marks the renewed hostility from surrounding Gentile peoples after the restoration of Jerusalem's temple.

verses.text: and made plans to destroy the children of Jacob who lived among them. They began attacking and killing some of the people.
verses.comment: Refers to the persecution and violence against Jewish communities scattered among the Gentiles.

verses.text: But Judas went out to fight the descendants of Esau in Idumea, at Akrabattene, because they lay in ambush for Israel. He struck them with great force, humbled them, and took their possessions.
verses.comment: Judas's campaign against the Idumeans continued Israel's hostile history with Edom.

verses.text: He also recalled the evil deeds of the sons of Baean, who were a constant trap and ambush for the people on the roads.
verses.comment: The sons of Baean are specifically noted for their harassment and danger to travelers.

verses.text: Judas surrounded them in their fortified towers; he set up camp against them, swore to wipe them out, and burned their towers along with all those inside.
verses.comment: Total destruction was a common approach in holy war narratives.

verses.text: Afterward, he turned to attack the Ammonites and found a large force there, led by Timothy.
verses.comment: The Ammonites lived east of the Jordan; Timothy appears as an enemy leader throughout 1 Maccabees.

verses.text: He fought many battles against them, defeated them thoroughly, and struck them down.
verses.comment: Judas's military success echoes victorious accounts in Judges.

verses.text: He captured Jazer with its surrounding villages, then returned to Judea.
verses.comment: Jazer was a significant town east of the Jordan.

verses.text: Meanwhile, the nations in Gilead gathered together against the Israelites who lived in their midst, intending to wipe them out. The Israelites fled to the stronghold at Dathema,
verses.comment: The Jewish communities in Gilead were under threat from their non-Jewish neighbors.

verses.text: and sent a letter to Judas and his brothers, saying, "The Gentiles near us have united to destroy us.
verses.comment: Appeals for help became a key motivation for Maccabean campaigns.

verses.text: "They are preparing to storm the stronghold where we have taken refuge, and Timothy leads their army.
verses.comment: Timothy emerges as the central adversary in Gilead.

verses.text: Please come at once and save us from their hands, for many of us have already been killed.
verses.comment: A plea for rescue in dire circumstances.

verses.text: "All our relatives in the land of Tob have been slaughtered. Their wives, children, and possessions have been taken, and about a thousand people have perished there."
verses.comment: References to the land of Tob may recall Jephthah in Judges 11.

verses.text: While the letter was being read, more messengers arrived from Galilee, their clothes torn, bringing a similar report.
verses.comment: Rending garments was a sign of mourning and distress.

verses.text: They told how people from Ptolemais, Tyre, Sidon, and all Gentile Galilee had united against them, with the intention "to wipe us out."
verses.comment: The threat now extends to Jewish communities in the north as well.

verses.text: Upon hearing these reports, Judas and the people gathered the assembly to consider how they could help their fellow Israelites in danger and under attack.
verses.comment: Judas calls a council to respond to simultaneous crises.

verses.text: Judas turned to his brother Simon and said, "Pick your men and go and rescue our people in Galilee. My brother Jonathan and I will head to Gilead."
verses.comment: The Maccabean leaders divide the rescue mission by region.

verses.text: He left Joseph, son of Zechariah, and Azariah, a leader among the people, with the remaining army in Judea to protect it,
verses.comment: Judea needs to be guarded while the main force is away.

verses.text: charging them, "Oversee these forces, but do not fight the Gentiles until we return."
verses.comment: Judas warns his deputies not to act aggressively in his absence.

verses.text: Three thousand men were assigned to Simon for the Galilean campaign, and eight thousand to Judas for Gilead.
verses.comment: A clear separation of military resources for each front.

verses.text: Simon marched into Galilee, fought many battles against the Gentiles, and overcame them.
verses.comment: Simon's successes echo those of Judas elsewhere.

verses.text: He chased them as far as the gate of Ptolemais. Around three thousand Gentiles were killed, and Simon took their spoils.
verses.comment: Loot taken in battle often provided essential resources.

verses.text: He then gathered up the Jews from Galilee and Arbatta, together with their wives, children, and belongings, and brought them with great joy to Judea.
verses.comment: The rescue of Jewish exiles is a key victory for Simon.

verses.text: Meanwhile, Judas Maccabeus and his brother Jonathan crossed the Jordan and traveled three days into the wilderness.
verses.comment: Crossing the Jordan recalls earlier Israelite ventures eastward.

verses.text: They met the Nabateans, who greeted them peacefully and told them everything that had happened to their fellow Jews in Gilead:
verses.comment: The Nabateans, an Arab people, play a neutral or supportive role here.

verses.text: "Many of your people have been trapped in Bozrah and Bosor, in Alema, Chaspho, Maked, and Carnaim—all fortified, large towns—
verses.comment: Lists places of Jewish refuge and siege east of the Jordan.

verses.text: "and some are being held in the other towns of Gilead. The enemy is preparing to attack tomorrow morning and take all these strongholds, planning to destroy everyone inside in a single day."
verses.comment: The threat of a coordinated massacre raises the stakes.

verses.text: At this, Judas and his army quickly took the wilderness road to Bozrah, attacked and conquered the town. He killed every male with the sword, took the spoils, and set the town on fire.
verses.comment: Follows the pattern of total destruction seen in other holy war stories.

verses.text: He departed that night and reached the fortress of Dathema.
verses.comment: The night march enabled a surprise or urgent approach.

verses.text: At sunrise they saw a countless army approaching, bringing ladders and siege engines to capture the stronghold, and attacking the Jews inside.
verses.comment: The numerically superior enemy is positioned for a major assault.

verses.text: Judas saw the battle had begun and heard the cries of the townspeople rising to Heaven, along with trumpets and loud calls.
verses.comment: Upward cries evoke appeals for divine intervention.

verses.text: So he told his soldiers, "Fight today for our brothers and sisters!"
verses.comment: Motivating his troops by appealing to kinship and duty.

verses.text: He advanced on the enemy from behind in three divisions, sounding their trumpets and calling out to God in prayer.
verses.comment: Battle formation and prayer demonstrate both strategy and reliance on God.

verses.text: When Timothy's army realized it was Maccabeus, they ran away in panic. He struck them hard—up to eight thousand died that day.
verses.comment: Judas's reputation contributed to his enemies' fear and defeat.

verses.text: Then Judas turned aside to Maapha, attacked it, conquered it, killed every man, looted it, and set it on fire.
verses.comment: A pattern of total destruction against hostile cities.

verses.text: From there he advanced and also seized Chaspho, Maked, Bosor, and the other cities of Gilead.
verses.comment: Lists the successful conquests in Gilead.

verses.text: After these events, Timothy raised a new army and set up camp opposite Raphon, across the stream.
verses.comment: Timothy quickly regroups; Raphon likely east of the Jordan.

verses.text: Judas sent scouts to spy on their camp, who reported, "All the Gentiles in the area have joined Timothy—a huge force.
verses.comment: Use of scouts shows advanced military tactics.

verses.text: "They've also hired Arabs for support. The enemy is camped across the stream, ready to battle you." Judas marched to confront them.
verses.comment: Highlights use of mercenaries and regional alliances.

verses.text: As Judas and his army approached the stream, Timothy said to his officers, "If Judas crosses over first, we can’t withstand him—he'll win.
verses.comment: Shows Timothy's fear and psychological assessment of the encounter.

verses.text: But if he's hesitant and makes camp on the other side, then we'll cross over and defeat him."
verses.comment: A plan based on predicting the enemy leader’s resolve.

verses.text: When Judas neared the stream, he stationed army officers there and commanded, "Don't let anyone stop—everyone must cross for battle."
verses.comment: Demonstrates Judas’s determination to press the attack.

verses.text: He himself led the charge across first, and the whole force followed. They defeated all the Gentile forces, who threw away their weapons and fled into the temple at Carnaim.
verses.comment: The enemy seeks sanctuary after being routed.

verses.text: Judas captured the city and burned the temple with everyone inside. That’s how Carnaim fell; after this, no one could stand against Judas.
verses.comment: This destruction signals the complete supremacy of Judas over these foes.

verses.text: Judas gathered every Israelite in Gilead, young and old, with their wives, children, and possessions—a very large group—to lead them back to Judah.
verses.comment: Echoes the Exodus as a people are led to safety.

verses.text: When they came to Ephron—a fortified, large city on their route—they found it impossible to bypass either on the right or left; they had to pass through it.
verses.comment: The city blocks the Israelites’ return route.

verses.text: But the townspeople had shut them out and barricaded the gates with stones.
verses.comment: The city’s resistance presents a final roadblock.

verses.text: Judas sent a peaceful message: "Let us pass through your land on our way home. We won’t harm anyone; we’ll travel only by foot." But they would not open the gates.
verses.comment: Judas offers assurances, but the city remains hostile.

verses.text: Judas then ordered his soldiers to set camp where they were.
verses.comment: A siege situation develops.

verses.text: The forces camped, and Judas fought against the city all that day and night, until he took it.
verses.comment: Persistent assault leads to success.

verses.text: He put every male to the sword, destroyed and plundered the city, and passed through over the bodies of the dead.
verses.comment: Total warfare as a warning and practical measure.

verses.text: They then crossed the Jordan River into the great plain before Beth-shan.
verses.comment: Beth-shan was a known strategic site near the Jordan.

verses.text: Judas pressed the stragglers forward and encouraged everyone until they reached the land of Judah.
verses.comment: Judas’s leadership extends to keeping everyone together on the journey.

verses.text: With joy and gladness, they climbed Mount Zion and offered burnt sacrifices, giving thanks that they all returned in safety; not one of them was lost.
verses.comment: A celebratory homecoming; thanksgiving sacrifices mark deliverance.

verses.text: While Judas and Jonathan were still in Gilead, and Simon was in Galilee near Ptolemais,
verses.comment: Places each commander during the ongoing campaigns.

verses.text: Joseph, son of Zechariah, and Azariah, the army commanders, heard of the brave feats and the battles Judas’s family had fought.
verses.comment: The deeds of the Maccabees inspire those left in charge.

verses.text: They said to themselves, "Let’s make a name for ourselves too by attacking the surrounding Gentiles."
verses.comment: Shows the desire for glory—possibly pride or ambition.

verses.text: So they gave the order to their troops and marched against Jamnia.
verses.comment: Their initiative was not in obedience to Judas’s instructions.

verses.text: But Gorgias and his men came out from the town and gave them battle.
verses.comment: Gorgias was a known Seleucid commander.

verses.text: Joseph and Azariah’s forces were defeated and chased all the way to the borders of Judea. About two thousand Israelites died that day.
verses.comment: Acting independently brought disaster.

verses.text: So the people suffered a crushing defeat, because instead of obeying Judas and his brothers, they tried to win glory for themselves.
verses.comment: Lack of obedience resulted in calamity, as in many biblical narratives.

verses.text: They did not belong to the kind of men through whom God granted deliverance to Israel.
verses.comment: Only special, chosen leaders brought true victory.

verses.text: But Judas and his brothers were greatly honored throughout Israel and among the surrounding nations, wherever their names were known.
verses.comment: Their renown spread for military prowess and leadership.

verses.text: People flocked to them, giving praise and admiration.
verses.comment: The Maccabees’ fame attracted supporters.

verses.text: Then Judas and his brothers went out to fight against the descendants of Esau in southern territory. He struck at Hebron and its surrounding villages, destroyed its fortresses, and set fire to the towers on every side.
verses.comment: Judas continues his campaigns to secure Judah’s borders.
verses.sectionHeader: Final Campaigns in the South and the Philistine Plain

verses.text: He then marched into the land of the Philistines, passing through Marisa.
verses.comment: Judas advances into new enemy territory.

verses.text: On that day, some priests, eager to display heroic courage, fell in battle because they went out to fight recklessly.
verses.comment: A cautionary note—zeal must be tempered with wisdom.

verses.text: Judas then turned aside to Azotus, in Philistine territory. He destroyed their altars, burned up the images of their gods, plundered the towns, and returned to Judea.
verses.comment: This demolition of pagan shrines closes the campaign, echoing earlier biblical models of eliminating idolatry.
